awd_titl_txt: INFEW/T2:WaterSmart: A Cyberinfrastructure-Based Integrated Agro-Geoinformatic Decision-Support Web Service System to Facilitate Informed Irrigation Decision-Making
awd_abstract_narration:
Irrigation significantly increases crop yields but consumes approximately 80% of consumptive water and 23-48% of all energy used in crop production in U.S. Therefore, developing low-cost efficient irrigation technologies, applicable at the state or even national level, will have significant impact in enhancing agricultural profitability and competitivity and environmental and economical health. Data-driven irrigation scheduling approaches, based on timely and reliable measures of crop, soil, and weather conditions, have demonstrated significant water and energy savings and economic and environmental benefits, but require farmers to have knowledge of the approaches and timely and reliable measures, which they don't normally possess. The project will strengthen food and energy security and environmental health of our nation, bring immense economic benefits to farmers, and help the US Department of Agriculture reach its 2030 sustainable agriculture goals. The goals are to save ~10% of overall irrigation water and energy usage, maximize irrigation returns on food and energy, and reduce farmer's required time and investment in irrigation management. 

WaterSmart, if successfully demonstrated in Nebraska, can be scaled to national level, resulting in a potential direct saving of 8.85 million acre-feet of water and $270 million in irrigation energy cost per year. WaterSmart will be built through maturing and systematically integrating recent advances in data-driven irrigation management, remote sensing, agro-geoinformatics, ontology-driven decision-making, modeling, Web service, and CI technologies. This project will automate data-driven approaches by developing a cyberinfrastructure (CI)-based integrated agro-geoinformatic decision-support Web service system, WaterSmart, and demonstrating its real-time operational capability for Nebraska at virtually no cost to farmers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Innovations at the Nexus of Food-Energy-

por.por_cntn:
Irrigation significantly increases crop yields but consumes approximately 80% of consumptive water and 23-48% of all energy used in crop production in U.S. Therefore, developing low-cost efficient irrigation technologies, applicable at the state or even national level, will have significant impact in enhancing agricultural profitability and competitivity and environmental and economical health. Data-driven irrigation scheduling approaches, based on timely and reliable measures of crop, soil, and weather conditions, have demonstrated significant water and energy savings and economic and environmental benefits, but require farmers to have knowledge of the approaches and timely and reliable measures, which they don’t normally possess. The objective of this project was to automate data-driven approaches by developing a cyberinfrastructure(CI)-based integrated agro-geoinformatic decision-support Web service system, WaterSmart, and demonstrating its real-time operational potentials for Nebraska at virtually no cost to farmers. The goals of the project were to save ~10% of overall irrigation water and energy usage, maximize irrigation returns on food and energy, and reduce farmers’ required time and investment in irrigation management.

The project has successfully realized the proposed objectives and goals. The project has developed and validated algorithms that combine the satellite remote sensing and high-resolution land surface models to automate the data-driven irrigation scheduling and prototyped the WaterSmart irrigation decision system with the algorithms. Testing and validation in Nebraska showed that comparing with the current operational irrigation scheduling, the automated data-driven irrigation scheduling provided by WaterSmart can save more than 40% of irrigation water in the wet years and over 10% in the dry years without impacting the crop yield.  This means that if a half of irrigated farms in Nebraska adopt the solution, up to 1 billion m3 of water and $100 million irrigation energy cost can be saved, and up to 1 million tons of CO2-equivalent GHG emission can be reduced per year. A follow-up project has been started to operationalize the automated data-driven irrigation scheduling service with national coverage. The project has provided significant help in reaching the goals of USDA’s research program to “reduce the use of energy, nitrogen fertilizer, and water by ten percent (based on 2010 usage)” by 2030 and of the Water for Agriculture Challenge Area to make “water availability for diverse agricultural uses: the right water for the right place and time.” The project helps the U.S. to enhance crop productivity while reducing irrigation water use and cost and maintaining agricultural sustainability.    

The project has produced one book, 2 Ph.D. dissertations, and over 40 peer-reviewed journal and conference publications, significantly advancing the data-driven irrigation management and associated remote sensing, agro-geoinformatics, ontology-driven decision-making, high-resolution land surface modeling, AI/machine learning, Web service, and cyberinfrastructure technologies.

This project has involved several young passionate scientists who have shown great talent and energy in carrying out scientific research and their performances reflect that they can become good contributing members to the research or industrial communities. This project has served as the fundamental step to support their future careers. The results of this project have been incorporated into multiple courses in three universities (George Mason University, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, and Purdue University). 


Last Modified: 04/19/2024
Modified by: Liping Di
